briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 26, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Signs and Warnings of the Climate Crisis
sections.content: Over the past three years, signs of 'unfamiliar climate change' have been detected domestically [1], and an analysis suggests that the Winter Olympics are also being negatively impacted by climate change [2]. Internationally, a blizzard that occurred in 2026 was intensified by climate change [25], and scientists have issued warnings that deadly storms in the Iberian and Moroccan regions were fueled by climate change [61, 62]. Furthermore, climate change is disrupting the famous migration of monarch butterflies [41] and is having widespread impacts on ecosystems, such as delaying the blooming period of tropical flowers by several weeks compared to usual [42, 43, 45, 46, 49, 50, 51, 52, 54, 56, 58, 59, 60, 64, 65]. The University of Reading has suggested that the list of climate change risks needs to be updated to avoid the worst impacts [48], reminding us that warnings about climate change from the past are recurring [66].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Carbon Neutrality and Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Korea has declared 2026 as the inaugural year of a major energy transition and demonstrated its mid-to-long-term commitment by announcing a roadmap to achieve the 100GW renewable energy target [17]. Several domestic local governments are operating carbon neutrality points and expanding the supply of zero-emission vehicles [3, 4, 6, 7, 9, 10], while Jeonbuk Self-Governing Province has joined ICLEI as a member city to advance its carbon neutrality policies [5]. Korea Western Power is making active efforts, including holding workshops to enhance practical capabilities in renewable energy development and operation, and establishing renewable energy promotion as a key mid-to-long-term strategy [11, 15, 18]. Furthermore, the 'Renewable Energy Self-Sufficient City Act' is slated to be pursued as a top legislative priority [14]. Ulsan City is exploring solutions for floating offshore wind power generation to leap forward as an 'energy capital' [22], and Jang Se-il, Mayor of Yeonggwang County, is encouraging citizen participation by stating that profits from renewable energy projects will be shared with residents or distributed as basic income [16, 21]. Internationally, the UN has approved the first carbon credits under the Paris Agreement's market mechanism [47], and in the UK, a renewable energy project utilizing Earth's heat to power 10,000 homes is set to proceed [67]. In Europe, knowledge development, sharing, and implementation for climate adaptation advancement through citizen participation are underway [38].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Climate Policy, Litigation, and Governance Controversies
sections.content: Domestically, a lively debate is ongoing regarding nuclear energy versus renewable energy in relation to climate change [13]. Internationally, the U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments from oil and gas companies seeking to block climate change-related lawsuits, intensifying legal battles [28, 32]. Criticism has been raised that governments are concealing climate change-related information by denying, delaying, and downplaying it [33]. The climate crisis is shaking up the homeowner's insurance market, and the insurance industry is resisting regulation [36, 44]. Concerns have been raised that the Trump administration's EPA declared no harm from climate change and could backfire by undermining climate change response capabilities [57, 63]. Meanwhile, experts have warned that an international shipping carbon tax is at risk of being derailed due to 'bullying' from the United States [68]. Efforts are also continuing to explore the climate preparedness of low- and middle-income countries and to uncover less documented impacts of climate change [31, 40].

sections.title: ğŸ“° Reassessment and New Understanding in Climate Science
sections.content: Research findings have been published indicating that the existing theory that melting glaciers could slow down climate change is being challenged [30, 34, 35]. Scientists previously believed that Antarctic ice melt helped combat climate change, but it has been revealed that this is not the case, leading to a reassessment of previous understandings [39]. Meanwhile, past climate change research also reported positive signs, with the first indicators of resilience appearing in tropical life when global warming did not exceed 1.5 degrees Celsius [29]. Separately, controversial geoengineering 'antacid' ocean experiments are underway to reverse climate change, sparking scientific and ethical debates [26].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted the severe signs of the climate crisis, alongside ongoing domestic and international efforts towards carbon neutrality and renewable energy transition. At the same time, it is important to note the various controversies surrounding climate policies and the advancements in scientific understanding. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: National Institute of Forest Science completes patent registration. articles.description: Panama joins smaller nations in dropping support for policy aimed at cutting maritime emissionsUS â€œbullyingâ€ over a proposed carbon levy on shipping appears to be paying off, experts have said, after Panama reversed its support for the measure.In a leaked document seen by the Guardian, the key maritime state has co-sponsored a proposal to the International Maritime Organization that would in effect cancel the carbon levy and undermine attempts to cut greenhouse gas emissions. summary.phenomenon: Panama has withdrawn its support for a maritime carbon tax policy, a move experts attribute to alleged 'bullying' by the United States over the proposed levy. Panama has co-sponsored a proposal to the International Maritime Organization (IMO) that would effectively cancel the carbon levy and undermine efforts to reduce maritime greenhouse gas emissions.
summary.cause: The United States' alleged 'bullying' regarding the proposed maritime carbon tax is identified as the cause for Panama's withdrawal of support and attempts to weaken the policy.
summary.outlook: This development could hinder efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the shipping sector.
